29.28.text:
Welcome to Fieldsports Britain. Coming up....Mark
Gilchrist is after 4 and 20 blackbirds to

35.64.text:
bake in his pie or may be bbq in his new series
Hunter Gatherer.

41.01.text: It has got me in it so it is bound to be doomed.

44.46.text:
Is this the bravest fox in Britain? We have
a special report.

49.01.text:
We've been sent a box of fox calls to give
away free. And we have a DVD competition prize

55.36.text:
First, Roy Lupton is keeping his options open.
He is Outfoxing with a little bit of roe stalking

67.74.text:
Finally, finally the UK has some sunshine
to brag about as well as a Wimbledon champion.

78.46.text:
But we don't want to be relaxing with a glass
of chilled pinot collapso and a grass-coated

83.24.text:
burnt sausage. We want to be Out Foxing, especially
when the grass that's not stuck to our banger

88.40.text:
has been freshly cut and foxes are on the
lookout for a cheap meal.

92.19.text:
It is that time of year again. We have got
about 26, 27 degrees absolutely roasting but

98.47.text:
the good thing is all the fields are getting
cut. Everything is being cut for hay. Everything

102.82.text:
has been cut today here. So we are going to
have a quick stalk around and it could be

107.64.text:
a bit of a mixed bag and I am hoping that
we might pick up quite a few foxes later on

112.34.text:
when they start coming out and we might also
pick up a roe buck or two as well. So fingers

118.10.text:
crossed we may have a successful evening.
Right let's get on.

121.12.text:
We haven't been on this bit of ground for
a couple of years. Last time, Roy had roe

125.09.text:
does dancing all around us during the rut
- but it looks like our first stalk of the

129.40.text:
evening might have to be sacrificed as Roy
has spotted a fox jumping through the long

134.08.text:
A fox was just walking along to our left hand
side. I have just done a little bit of ... squeaking,

143.86.text:
but it is a bit of a crunch time because we
are coming up to where there are normally

149.85.text:
a few roe getting about so I don't really
want to make too much of a noise and a kerfuffle

152.58.text:
and start really heavily calling. We will
just slowly stroll up and see if the foxes

154.24.text:
are up there now. That is a shame as he was
probably just heading out to the field that

162.74.text:
This is the time of year in the UK when bucks
are bold and foxes are foolish - perfect for

167.60.text:
anyone out to shoot both. We keep steady and
20 paces further along our fox pops out into

173.73.text:
the open. Lady luck may be with us after all.
With a bit of prompting, eventually Roy also

179.12.text:
notices the fox. It drops where it stands
on the ride.

182.88.text:
Best made plans and all that. It was a shame
we had t shoot it then because as I say we

199.06.text:
were just coming up into the main area where
the roe are but that same fox had us walking

204.42.text:
out all of a sudden where we had been just
very quiet and just slowly strolling up and

208.92.text:
he walked out straight in front of us there.
First one in for the evening and away we go.

216.07.text:
It is a vixen which has obviously had cubs.
This time of the year the vixens tend to be

220.29.text:
out hunting a little bit earlier. She was
obviously mooching around trying to find a

224.33.text:
few meals for the cubs. But the cubs at this
stage are going to be quite well on. So I

229.35.text:
would have thought come the evening the cubs
are going to be out crossing about on the

233.76.text:
field and hopefully we can account for them
then.

236.26.text:
Shooting the fox may have blown Roy's chance
of a deer but it's not a complete dead loss.

241.06.text:
Sometimes you get a sense there must be deer
here, because if I were a deer I'd be happy

248.69.text:
We make our way through another small wood.
At the end of the ride we see a doe grazing

257.87.text:
We have got deer in all the surrounding fields,
but none where we have got permission. So

264.71.text:
... this place has normally got quite a few
on it, but it has been ruined over the last

268.99.text:
couple of years because there have been a
lot of sheep grazing on here. So I am sure

271.55.text:
the deer are around but not in the same numbers
they used to be.

275.60.text:
But then Roy's x-ray vision kicks in and a
glass across this high standing grass reveals

280.86.text: a young buck looking our way.

282.63.text:
So because we are losing light and we want
to get onto the fields to set up for the foxes

288.91.text:
coming out before it gets dark we are going
to try and push our luck, walk along the top

293.17.text:
here and hope that he goes down and then stops
and presents us with a shot. Normally in these

300.04.text:
circumstances it always goes wrong, but you
never know David might have turned into a

309.14.text: good luck charm rather than a jinx.

311.95.text:
We work our way around. Making steady progress,
Roy gets above the animal and even gets the

316.03.text:
sticks up but the gamble doesn't pay off - the
buck heads to the shelter of the wood and

323.52.text:
All is not lost and we head back up towards
the ride we just came down - we get a glimpse

328.39.text: of him in the clearing but he's gone again.

330.07.text:
That is a shame. We have come back up the
ride he came up and he must of switched back

337.57.text:
and gone back to the stand that he was on.
There is probably a bigger buck in the main

341.67.text:
part of the wood and he doesn't want to encroach
upon his territory too much. So we are going

348.03.text:
to go down that way to get onto the foxes
anyway. We might still come across him again.

352.42.text:
What to do? We walk back around and, luckily,
in the 10 minutes or so we've taken our buck

358.25.text:
appears to have settled down to munch in a
field further down the valley.

362.77.text: Again the height of the grass is an issue.

364.82.text:
What we are going to do every time he puts
his head down and starts feeding we are going

370.23.text:
to make a few steps in. If he puts his head
up we are camouflaged quite well against the

376.22.text:
back stop of this wood. Even though we are
walking along the edge of it we are just going

380.44.text:
to see if we can get right up on him. He is
down again feeding so we will try and take

389.29.text:
a few steps towards him. We are probably only
about 70 yards away. But I just want to try

398.10.text:
and get it so we have got a clearer path for
the bullet.

416.03.text:
So stupidly I didn't bring my dog to track
it, but luckily in this long grass I just

422.22.text:
tracked it as it ran and it went forward and
hopefully dropped just between those two trees.

427.61.text:
What I want to do is just have a run up, check
the blood and then we will move into him.

432.41.text:
Some stalks can be physically taxing, uncomfortable,
others straightforward, all have their own

437.55.text:
rewards. This has had a bit of everything.
Roy has had to think on his feet, second-guessing

442.34.text:
this buck, getting it wrong, then using the
natural cover and understanding the buck's

445.88.text:
behaviour to move in close enough for a clear
chest shot. Deer have a special technique

450.93.text:
to catch a potential predator with its proverbial
pants down and Roy has shown how to by-pass

456.59.text:
A lot of the time when you are stalking up
on them like that, they will dip their heads

460.02.text:
as if they are going to feed just long enough
for you to start moving and bolt their heads

465.01.text:
right up again. And that again is obviously
millions of years of evolution in waiting

471.08.text:
for predators or looking for predators stalking
up on them. So just wait a couple of seconds,

475.33.text:
once they have got their heads down before
you start moving.

478.56.text:
Roy cleans the animal and skins it for the
landowner. It's now much later than we'd hoped

483.05.text:
so no more daylight foxing. It's out with
the lamp.

487.28.text:
But first it's the bright lights of the local
kebab shop protract us moth-like.

491.91.text:
What we are going to do is put the caller
out in the middle of the field and we are

496.19.text:
just going to have a scan around with the
tack light and see if we can pick up the eyes.

498.93.text:
I have got the red LED in again. Although
the cubs shouldn't be lamp shy. I just like

503.73.text:
using the red LED to kick off just in case
we come across any wise vixens or dogs that

508.47.text:
are still out there. So we got the vixen a
little bit earlier on. We are going to start

513.06.text:
off there and hopefully the cubs might be
venturing out and they might be on that freshly

517.24.text:
cut field there, just looking for some mice
what have you and as I say we are just going

521.68.text:
to put a few light rodent distress call out
first. See if we get any customers there.

526.74.text: So hopefully we will get some visitors.

529.38.text:
Having had a fox in daylight, it seems a foregone
conclusion that we'll call some in at night

533.30.text:
especially on this freshly cut hay crop - but
the first stand delivers nothing. The odds

539.14.text:
move out dramatically at the second stand,
with mist lifting off the lake. Our visibility

543.90.text:
is reduced but it does make the Nightmaster
800 look like a light sabre though!

548.85.text:
The foxes could be having a party 50 yards
away and we wouldn't know what is going on.

552.27.text:
We are getting that time-for-bed feeling -feeling
slightly light headed, not from too much sun

556.49.text:
and Italian plonk, but from the thrill of
a successful bit of daylight foxing and a

560.93.text: buck we had to work hard for.

564.43.text:
Roy making the most of his evening there.
If you want to see more roe stalking click

568.35.text:
on the screen which has magically appeared
up there behind me. Now, looking more bronzed

572.96.text:
than "The Hoff" it's David on the fieldsportschannel
news stump.

586.48.text:
Despite recording scenes like this for the
film The Mask, actor Jim Carrey has apologised

592.50.text:
to American gun owners for calling them heartless
motherf*****s. He has also pulled out from

598.10.text:
publicity surrounding his new movie, Kick
Ass 2, after saying it is too violent

605.18.text:
Shooting organisations from all over the world
could learn from US waterfowl conservancy

610.62.text:
Ducks Unlimited. To spread the word, and thanks
to a corporate partner, Basspro, its colours

616.30.text:
are on board the second placed Tony Stewart's
car in the Daytona Coke Zero 400 NASCAR race.

623.48.text:
With deer, apparently it is not always flight
not fight. This turned up in our inbox from

628.23.text:
Belgian hunting website Hunting.be. Don't
know how old it is, but it shows the dangers

633.72.text: of walking dogs near angry does.

637.48.text:
And finally, maybe the silly season has started
early, and maybe it took more than a few takes,

642.46.text:
but this man certainly knows how to catch
fish. Douglas Owen catches his dinner completely

647.19.text:
organically. Trout For Dinner 1 is a YouTube
sensation.

652.23.text:
You are now up to date with Fieldsports Britain
News. Stalking the stories. Fishing for facts.

663.73.text:
Thank you David. Strangely dissimilar to Baywatch.
Now let's spread a little love around the

668.81.text:
fieldsports channel community. It's Hallo
Charlie.

676.12.text: Here is what the world is up to this week.

679.18.text:
Hallo Charlie. We are in ... and we are about
to go shooting. We have got water pipit, Lal

687.06.text:
and his brother Shaun, there is Claude and
you will just see what you going to have happen

694.68.text:
today. We are hoping to get some, but we will
see. At the moment it is quite quiet, but

697.43.text: it should heat up just now.

698.62.text:
Hallo Charlie. This is Cameron shooting rabbits
out in Rochdale.

703.36.text:
Hallo Charlie. This is Max from Hertfordshire,
beautiful sunny evening. Just broken up for

708.63.text:
holidays so I thought I would go out for a
start of the holiday's wander with the air

713.51.text:
rifle and I have had some success. Saw it
a way off and popped it at 34 yards. Hopefully

720.13.text: the first of many for the holidays.

723.47.text:
Send us your own Hallo Charlie. Film yourself
on your mobile phone with just a sentence

728.15.text:
saying hallo Charlie who you are and what
you are up to. Then share it or email it via

732.67.text:
Youtube, Facebook, Dropbox or Yousendit, Younameit
to Charlie@fieldsportschannel.tv

738.51.text:
Right urban foxes. We love a good urban fox
story, because we love the look on Brian May's

743.73.text:
face. When we were shown this footage coming
up we just had to find out more. Now for fear

748.35.text:
of a public backlash we have agreed to protect
this homeowner's identity.

755.01.text:
The Urban foxes debate gets people red in
the face hot under the collar - Last summer

760.82.text:
there was even a week's worth of programmes
dedicated to it on British Freeview TV. Channel

766.98.text:
4's Foxes Live did little to open the debate
and I was left feeling I was the one that

771.65.text:
had been thrown to the dogs after Brian and
the gang sat teeth bared with noses wet and

776.90.text:
coats shiny under the studio lights� Oh
those tumbling locks. But, foxes are a problem

783.21.text: even if some won't choose to believe it.

785.75.text:
Look at this footage taken by a couple in
Sussex. This brazen fox starts coming into

791.54.text:
their utility room through the cat flap helping
itself to the cat food during the night - it

796.52.text:
then starteds breaking into the dog food,
having a snooze and the.. the mucky pup. In

801.83.text:
case you are wondering, this footage is captured
on a trailcam after several nights of mystery

806.22.text:
visits and the titbits on the floor are there
to assist with capturing the culprit on camera.

812.31.text:
This anonymous home owner, having heard stories
of urban fox attacks is now concerned for

817.94.text:
the safety of his cat, his dogs and even his
wife... We're carefully keeping his identity

823.99.text:
a secret for fear of reprisals from Brian
and other angry rock legends.

829.37.text:
It concerns me really because at the end of
the day how far are they going to go are they,

833.76.text:
we have got a couple of cats, are they going
to attack the cats, are they going to attack

837.07.text:
the dogs. And above all that I really don't
want them to become vicious and come in the

841.37.text:
house and attack Kate. It would be awful for
her I don't know what she would end up catching.

849.97.text:
OK. There really is no point in trying to
conceal the identity of world champion shot

853.69.text:
Mr George Digweed. But can he believe that
a wild animal has the confidence to enter

858.76.text:
such a foreign environment especially when
there's so much natural food about?

863.18.text:
To actually come into a house in a village
has certainly opened my eyes up to where they

867.91.text:
will go and what they will do. I am sure there
is plenty of rats and mice and that sort of

872.66.text:
thing about. There will be a lot of young
rabbits about that are fairly docile and easy

879.34.text:
to catch. I find the whole thing astonishing
that it can come into the house especially

883.59.text:
the house of someone who shoots about 250
a year doing a pest control job.

889.41.text:
The obvious question is: what is going to
happen to the bravest fox in britain? As yet

898.42.text:
George Digweed proving difficult to keep under
wraps. And if you want to win a signed copy

902.48.text:
of George's Digging for Gold DVD, please visit
our Facebook page where you have to count

907.46.text:
the number of crows and jackdaws in this photograph...
film of the big day to follow soon.

914.20.text:
Next Mark Gilchrist has a new series about
hunting and cooking- it's evolution in progress

929.16.text:
It's the summer solstice - the longest day,
and Mark is on a date with girl friend Natalie

934.67.text:
who's going to experience her first romantic
evening out rabbit shooting. It's a good job

941.04.text:
Mark has his and hers outfits on test from
new kids on the block ShooterKing from Belgium.

946.71.text: Natalie is going to need it.

948.96.text:
Two is company, three is a crowd and four
o'clock in the morning is when Mark wants

953.30.text:
to see us next. That's in six hours' time,
when Mark is going to have a go at the local

959.70.text:
They bring quite a lot of disease into the
cattle feeders. It is all stored in open bins

962.51.text:
and then they mix it up and feed it to the
cows and they carry disease and also the farmer

969.19.text: doesn't want to feed 150 crows every morning.

973.64.text:
He is being joined by Zeiss pro stalker Alex
Hinkin who is setting up on the other side

979.44.text:
And most of your stuff is going to come over
like this or back from behind you. Like that

982.42.text:
yes. But as soon as you start banging they
will start moving towards the farmyard.

988.10.text: Ok where are you from here?

994.61.text:
Now the point of Hunter Gatherer is to eat
what we shoot... hmm... not sure how that

1001.81.text:
got there... We are a bit late with this one.
The traditional date for shooting young rooks,

1006.97.text:
or branchers, is the 12th May. We know stuff
is late coming-on this year, but this is really

1012.87.text:
pushing it - So what do blackbirds baked in
a pie taste like?

1017.15.text:
Well they are supposed to taste like pigeon.
If they were dead everyone would eat them.

1024.66.text:
So I am naturally quite sceptical. I made
rook pie as in branchers in a pie for Sporting

1033.69.text:
Shooter two or three years ago. It was pleasant
I suppose, but I wouldn't rush out to eat

1043.98.text:
it again. But if there was nothing else to
eat I would eat it.

1048.27.text:
As the nursery rhyme goes it's 4 and 20 blackbirds,
so what does that really add up to?

1052.92.text:
Well 4 and 20 is probably 80 so we have some
way to go before we can make a pie. I don't

1058.43.text:
think we are even going to have enough for
a small casserole if we carry on like this.

1063.60.text:
With the way the morning is going probably
best to stick to 24.

1068.41.text:
13 unlucky for some. 14, 15 we might get the
80 yet. 16, 4 and 20.

1090.94.text:
It's been a slow start but Mark is able to
get his eye in. He is loving this work.

1096.72.text:
Oh yes. Oh. Tell me you have got that one
David. Oh yes. Oh yes. Oh man. I know you

1119.99.text:
As well as his smart ShooterKing jacket which
we all know looks too good for Mr Gilchrist

1124.76.text:
and will get as cleaned as regularly as his
guns - i.e. not at all - he is also giving

1129.86.text:
a Mossberg pump action shotgun from York Guns
a work out. These days, the pump action seems

1136.13.text:
to come second place to the semi auto. Mark
does not really understand why. It's a practical

1141.59.text:
way of getting shots down the barrel, especially
in a hide- situation. It requires a modicum

1146.61.text:
more skill than a semi-auto but there s less
to go wrong. Pumps don't jam like autos can.

1152.31.text:
I am not trying to be rude, but I think a
lot of people think they need to fire lots

1155.83.text:
of shots really quickly. Anyone that is buying
a gun because its fast cycling is never going

1163.25.text:
to make a bag of anything. So I think people
think they are getting something good if they

1169.69.text:
can get through the shells really quickly.
But if you see a really good shot like Andy

1175.49.text:
Crow firing three shots, he will probably
go bang ... bang ..... bang. The shots are

1184.21.text:
probably that far apart because if you are
doing it any quicker you are guessing where

1190.01.text:
your next shot is going. You very rarely go
bang, bang, bang and get three kills, because

1193.98.text:
you are just not taking the line of the bird
properly. I think that is why people go for

1198.54.text:
autos over pumps. I must say I am quite fond
of a pump.

1206.96.text:
Mark has also got a silenced Mossbeg .410
on test too and we'll be playing with that

1211.34.text:
in an upcoming episode. He is pretty pleased
with that too.

1216.07.text:
With tummies rumbling and nearly 80 birds
on the floor it looks like crow for breakfast

1220.74.text:
... or maybe not - the garage-bought disposable
bbq just isn't making it... plus we're feeling

1226.87.text:
pretty sorry for Natalie - yes, remember Natalie?
- she's trying to get some sleep in Mark's

1231.72.text:
van and to be honest she'd prefer she had
some cornflakes and a coffee.

1235.59.text:
Ok so it was quite a good morning. It wasn't
as good as I hoped it would be. We picked

1241.15.text:
76, I thought we would get 120, 150 so it
is a bit disappointing from that point of

1246.63.text:
view. We were going to round it up with a
bbq with a young rook, but we failed on quite

1252.91.text:
a few levels. Firstly, that is a jackdaw and
not a rook and David just can't light a disposable

1258.70.text:
bbq, which between us is quite a poor effort
for hunter gatherer if we one can't hunt and

1264.66.text:
gather the right thing and two can't make
fire. I think the series might be doomed.

1269.21.text:
Fear not we will eat branchers next year and
even crow at some point. Maybe some of you

1274.69.text:
can tell us what it tastes like and the best
way to cook it?

1278.60.text:
Thank you Mark. Next time we will cook something
I promise. Right - the best of YouTube this

1291.08.text:
This is Hunting YouTube, which aims to show
the best hunting, shooting and fishing videos

1296.15.text:
Let's start with a trailer for a hunting DVD
- but a good one. Predator Hunting Suppressed

1300.69.text:
six pack (The Kill Shot) is the highlight
of the video you can buy, showing a pack of

1305.41.text:
seven, actually, not six coyotes charging
a call.

1308.23.text:
Staying in North America and grackle hunting
is a popular sport with airgunners. Varmint

1313.00.text:
HunterHP is using, as an keen airgunner would
hope and expect, a .22-calibre Gamo Varmint

1319.19.text:
We remain with Americans but we move to Slovakia
in this film where Sean Finley, outdoor concierge

1324.52.text:
(great job that) with the High Adventure Company
is escorting clients from the Metropolitan

1328.57.text:
Club in Washington DC on driven pheasant shooting
and a spot of culture behind the old iron

1334.02.text:
Now for our first fishing foray this week,
it's an unusual method sent in by James Marchington.

1338.14.text:
A man with a pet mink - well there has to
be one - Joseph Carter says he is training

1342.56.text:
his furry friend Monchu how to catch fish
in the wild. Born and raised in a mink farm,

1349.93.text:
this is his second fishing trip and the little
beggar strikes gold. Mr Carter reckons it's

1355.67.text:
Staying with fishing and I am struck by Dieter
Danowski - not literally I am glad to say

1360.18.text:
for he is here spearfishing a 16kg Spanish
mackerel in Queensland, Australia. He shoots

1365.04.text: this one at Sunken Reef, near Yeppoon.

1367.68.text:
Australia offers sport of all kinds and this
video, Swamp Hogs, is a bowhunting film recommended

1371.94.text:
by a viewer called Robert from Brisbane. Thank
you Robert. Shot in the Northern Territory,

1376.46.text:
this is a pleasantly expensive production.
Robert writes: "It's some great pig hunting

1380.34.text:
here in Oz. There's even a big-arse croc in
this."

1383.02.text:
Red Stag & Fallow Buck Hunting New Zealand
May 2013 with the floridly-named Ample Hunting

1388.23.text: shows two weeks of great deerstalking.

1391.24.text:
And finally we are back in London for of one
of the many gunmaking firms called Rigby.

1395.31.text:
There was John Rigby, which passed into American
ownership a few years ago, there was another

1399.75.text:
John Rigby in London which last year agreed
to stop using the name, and there is now a

1403.99.text:
Rigby owned by the people who own Blaser Rifles.
Look at all the Rigbys - where do they all

1408.71.text:
come from? This film marks the relaunch of
Rigby as a London gunmaker and is a production

1414.02.text: by the shooting writer Michael Yardley.

1417.27.text:
You can click on any of these films to watch
them. If you have a YouTube film you would

1421.15.text:
like us to pop in to the weekly top eight,
send it in via YouTube, or email me the link

1428.95.text:
We are back next week but first, it's competition
time. It's our super Chinese panda give away.

1436.43.text:
This is my daughter Daisy who has been looking
after the Panda. Show the panda Daisy. Now

1440.37.text:
we asked you how you like Pandas. We like
them with onion rings and we also asked you

1445.85.text:
when the panda appeared in our Chinese programme.
Lots of you sent in your entries and Daisy

1452.26.text:
will now pick a winner and Daisy it is you.
No it's not it is Dave Brennan. Pandas are

1460.45.text:
clever skating behind that photographer on
tele says Dave. Well Dave, Panda coming out

1466.56.text:
Now a slightly more useful competition, we
have got fox calls from Steve Larsson in Australia.

1471.22.text:
I won't attempt to blow them now. You can
have a click on the screen how to do it. We

1479.83.text:
have got more Facebook competitions coming
up later this week including tickets to the

1484.54.text:
CLA Game Fair that you can win and talking
of the Game Fair we have got our big screen

1488.61.text:
at the Gunmakers pub at Gunmakers Road. Drop
by for a chat. This has been Fieldsports Britain.
